title: 110_s2213
content: The "Cyber-Crime Act of 2007" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 amends the United States Code to include conspiracy to commit cyber-crimes. Section 3 addresses fixing loopholes with cyber-extortion. SEC. 3 amends Section 1030(a)(7) of title 18, US Code to address cyber-extortion by threatening damage to a protected computer, unauthorized access to information, or demanding money in relation to computer damage. SEC. 4 amends Section 1030(a)(5)(B) of title 18, US Code to include damage affecting 10 or more protected computers in a 1-year period. It also updates Section 2332b(g)(5)(B)(i) to reference the protection of computers. SEC. 5 modifies Section 1961(1)(B) to include section 1030 in relation to fraud and computer-related activities. SEC. 6 amends Section 1030(a)(2)(C) by removing the requirement of an interstate or foreign communication for certain offenses involving protected computers. It also broadens the scope by amending Section 1030(e)(2)(B) to include "affecting" after "which is used in". SEC. 7 introduces civil forfeiture for violations of Section 1030. Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include civil forfeiture provisions. The court must order the forfeiture of any property used to commit the offense or obtained as a result of the violation. The amendment to Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code includes civil forfeiture provisions for property used in or obtained from the violation. Seizures and forfeitures will follow procedures outlined in chapter 46 of title 18, with duties typically assigned to the Secretary of the Treasury now performed by designated officers under the Secretary of Homeland Security. Criminal forfeiture of property, seizure, disposition, and related proceedings will be governed by section 2461(c) of title 28, United States Code. The civil forfeiture provisions for property used in or obtained from violations will be governed by section 413 of the Comprehensive Drug Abuse and Prevention Control Act of 1970. Property of violators or those acting with them, used to commit violations, gross proceeds, and related property will be subject to forfeiture. Directive to Sentencing Commission. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and adjust its guidelines for offenses related to computer crime and data theft to increase penalties as mandated by Congress. Factors such as deterrence of such crimes must be considered in formulating appropriate sentences. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and adjust guidelines for computer crime and data theft offenses, considering factors like sophistication, financial motive, loss incurred, and intent to cause harm. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and adjust guidelines for computer crime and data theft offenses, considering factors like harm caused, privacy violations, impact on government operations, critical infrastructure interference, public health threats, and involvement of juveniles. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review guidelines for computer crime and data theft offenses, considering factors like harm caused, privacy violations, impact on government operations, critical infrastructure interference, public health threats, involvement of juveniles, and whether personal information was disclosed during the offense. The Commission must ensure consistency with other directives and sentencing guidelines. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review guidelines for computer crime and data theft offenses, considering factors like harm caused, privacy violations, impact on government operations, critical infrastructure interference, public health threats, involvement of juveniles, and whether personal information was disclosed during the offense. The Commission must ensure consistency with other directives and sentencing guidelines, account for aggravating or mitigating circumstances, make conforming changes to the guidelines, and ensure they meet the purposes of sentencing as set forth in the law. SEC. 9. ADDITIONAL FUNDING FOR RESOURCES TO INVESTIGATE AND PROSECUTE CRIMINAL ACTIVITY INVOLVING COMPUTERS. Additional funding of $10,000,000 each for the Secret Service, FBI, and Attorney General to investigate and prosecute crimes involving computers and information technology. Funds are available until expended.
